Connecticut School Shooting

US grapples with deaths of innocent kids

A sign outside of a local business in downtown Newtown read, 'Our hearts are broken, our spirits are strong', the morning following the mass shooting. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
Volunteer firefighters carried flowers to a makeshift memorial near the Sandy Hook Elementary school. Mary Altaffer/AP photo
Distraught residents left the fire station after hearing news of their loved ones from officials in Newtown, Conn. Don Emmert/AFP/Getty Images
A tribute by the Brazilian association Rio de Paz to the victims on the beach of Copacabana in Rio de Janeiro. World leaders expressed shock and horror over the massacre. Christophe Simon/AFP/Getty Images
Gary Seri hung a message written on a table cloth in honor of the teachers who died along with students when a gunman open fire at Sandy Hook Elementary School. Julio Cortez/AP photo
Lt. J. Paul Vance of the Connecticut State Police conducted a news briefing Saturday,, where he gave the latest updates in the school shooting. Jason DeCrow/AP photo
People gathered for a vigil outside the White House in Washington, DC, following the Connecticut elementary school shooting. Antonov Mladen/AFP/Getty Images
A message for the victims was written on a candle outside the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church, in Newtown, Conn. David Goldman/AP photo
A message along the highway spoke to the grief of the Sandy Hook community. Spencer Platt/Getty Images
Balloons hung from the Sandy Hook School sign as residents of the small Connecticut community of Newtown were reeling on Saturday from one of the worst mass shootings in US history. Shannon Stapleton/Reuters
An American flag was at half-staff as dawn broke Saturday in Newtown, Conn. Jason DeCrow/AP photo
People gathered for a prayer vigil at St. Rose Church following the elementary school shooting in Newtown, Conn. Ammanuek Dunande/AFP/Getty Images
The tribute in Brazil contained a message for the victims and mourners in the Connecticut shooting as people across the globe mourned the tragedy. Christophe Simon/AFP/Getty Images
The families of victims grieved near Sandy Hook Elementary School. Adrees Latif/Reuters
President Obama wiped his eye as he spoke about the elementary school shooting. Charles Dharapak/AP
A woman waited to hear about her sister, a teacher, following the shooting at the school. Jessica Hill/AP
Young children waited outside Sandy Hook Elementary School after the shooting. Michelle McLoughlin/Reuters
Connecticut State Police led children from the Sandy Hook Elementary School. Shannon Hicks, Newtown Bee/AP

Police find 'very good' evidence on gunman

State police Lt. Paul Vance said they hoped the evidence would answer questions about the gunman's motives. (AP, 3:07 p.m.)
  • Firing ranges searched
  • Sympathy spanning the globe
  • SBS: Sports world supportive
  • Police, world look for a motive
  • 26 killed, including 20 kids

No rise in mass killings

Those who study mass shootings said they are not becoming more common, but their impact is huge. (AP, 3:12 p.m.)
  • A gun-control tipping point?
  • Fox: No easy solutions
  • Gold: Mental health care
  • The Angle Need gun control

Media struggle with facts

Pressed with the story's urgency, the media reported "facts" that were often in conflict or wrong. (AP, 3:10 p.m.)

Victim IDs expected

Authorities said they have the victims' identities. (AP, 1:10 p.m.)

Gunman recalled as intelligent, but remote

Those who knew him remember Adam Lanza as many things — intelligent, nerdy, goth, thin. (AP)

Connecticut School Shooting

Police: Conn. victims include 12 girls, 8 boys

The children who were killed at the Sandy Hook Elementary School were ages 6 and 7, according to police. The adults who died were women. (Globe, 5:13 p.m.)
  • Dad recalls 6-year-old | Funeral homes offer help
  • Media struggle with facts | Key facts about shooting
  • Conn. gov: Love pours in | How to talk to kids

A glimpse at the school shooting victims

The trail of loss in Newtown was more than many could bear: 20 children and six adults at the school and the gunman’s mother at home. (AP, 4:39 p.m.)
  • Teacher: Gunman didn't feel pain | Police seek motive
  • No rise in mass killings  |  A gun-control tipping point?
  • Fox: No easy solutions | Gold: Mental health care
  • SBS: Sports world supportive | editorial Need action
People grieved next to a makeshift memorial of flowers and balloons next to the Sandy Hook Elementary school sign. Shannon Stapleton/Reuters
A sign was seen near Sandy Hook Elementary School as residents of the small Connecticut community reeled from the shooting. Eric Thayer/Reuters
Two women embraced near a memorial close to Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn. Justin Lane/EPA
Mary Fellows,of Newtown, Conn., wept while waiting for a prayer service to begin at St John's Episcopal Church on Saturday, Dec. 15. David Goldman/AP photo
A message for the victims was written on a candle outside the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church, in Newtown, Conn. David Goldman/AP photo
Gary Seri hung a message written on a table cloth in honor of the teachers who also died. Julio Cortez/AP photo
A tribute to the victims on the beach of Copacabana in Rio de Janeiro. World leaders expressed shock and horror over the massacre. Christophe Simon/AFP/Getty Images
A sign outside of a local business in Newtown read, 'Our hearts are broken, our spirits are strong', the morning following the mass shooting. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images

Clinton recovering after fainting and suffering a concussion

Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, who skipped an overseas trip this past week because of a stomach virus, sustained a concussion after fainting, the State Department said today.
 (AP, 12:48 p.m.)

Cause sought in W. Bridgewater fire

No one was living at the house, which was under construction, when a fire erupted today at 2 a.m., officials said. (Boston Globe, 4:18 p.m.)

Opinion | Joan Vennochi

'Gun control' treated
like vile curse words

“Gun control” isn’t an expletive. There must be a conversation about it because we need to do more to protect our children and ourselves.

Both parties embrace Kerry

President Obama could nominate Senator John F. Kerry for secretary of state as early as next week.
Opinion | Derrick Z. Jackson

A successful model for urban
cycling in Portland, Ore.

Portland led the way in taking the risk out of cycling with master planning that today aims for cycling to account for 25 percent of city trips by 2030.

Local government cuts hit economy

Since the recession ended in 2009, local governments have eliminated nearly 500,000 jobs, including 10,000 in Massachusetts.
Opinion | Lawrence Harmon

Judging the judges in Mass.

Judicial independence is alive and well in Mass. where judges enjoy appointments until age 70. It’s judicial accountability that is dying a painful death.

Young girl returns the gift of giving

Kaia Rose Sooknanan-Andrew, 7, who spent a Christmas at Tufts Medical Center remembered the presents she received and decided to do the same for others.
Opinion | Adrian Walker

Newtown tragedy was preventable

Every single one of these shooting rampages might have been prevented if getting hold of a gun in this country was as difficult as, say, getting a driver’s ­license.
